verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:1
verses.text: Decrees of Fabian: Taken from the Decretal of Gratian.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:3
verses.text: That the man who refuses to be reconciled to his brother should be reduced by the severest fastings.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:4
verses.text: If any injured person refuses to be reconciled to his brother, when he who has injured him offers satisfaction, he should be reduced by the severest fastings, even until he accepts the satisfaction offered him with thankful mind.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:6
verses.text: The man is rendered infamous who knowingly presumes to forswear himself.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:7
verses.text: Whosoever has knowingly forsworn himself, should be put for forty days on bread and water, and do penance also for the seven following years; and he should never be without penance; and he should never be admitted to bear witness.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:8
verses.text: After this, however, he may enjoy communion.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:10
verses.text: A man and a woman subject to madness cannot enter into marriage.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:11
verses.text: Neither can a mad man nor a mad woman enter into the marriage relation.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:12
verses.text: But if it has been entered, then they shall not be separated.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:14
verses.text: Marriage relations in the fifth generation may unite with each other; and in the fourth generation, if they are found, they should not be separated.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:15
verses.text: Concerning relations who enter affinity by the connection of husband and wife, these, on the decease of wife or husband, may form a union in the fifth generation; and in the fourth, if they are found, they should not be separated.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:16
verses.text: In the third degree of relationship, however, it is not lawful for one to take the wife of another on his death.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:17
verses.text: In an equable manner, a man may be united in marriage after his wife's death with those who are his own kinswomen, and with the kinswomen of his wife.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:19
verses.text: Those who marry a wife allied by blood, and are separated, shall not be at liberty, as long as both parties are alive, to unite other wives with them in marriage, unless they can plead the excuse of ignorance.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:21
verses.text: Blood connections alone, or, if offspring entirely fails, the old and trustworthy, should reckon the matter of propinquity in the synod.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:22
verses.text: No alien should accuse blood connections, or reckon the matter of consanguinity in the synod, but relations to whose knowledge it pertains,—that is, father and mother, sister and brother, paternal uncle, maternal uncle, paternal aunt, maternal aunt, and their children.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:23
verses.text: If, however, offspring entirely fails, the bishop shall make inquiry canonically of the older and more trustworthy persons to whom the same relationship may be known; and if such relationship is found, the parties should be separated.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:25
verses.text: Every one of the faithful should communicate three times a year.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:26
verses.text: Although they may not do it more frequently, yet at least three times in the year should the laity communicate, unless one happen to be hindered by any more serious offences,—to wit, at Easter, and Pentecost, and the Lord's Nativity.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:28
verses.text: A presbyter should not be ordained younger than thirty years of age.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:29
verses.text: If one has not completed thirty years of age, he should in no way be ordained as presbyter, even although he may be extremely worthy; for even the Lord Himself was baptized only when He was thirty years of age, and at that period He began to teach.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 1:30
verses.text: It is not right, therefore, that one who is to be ordained should be consecrated until he has reached this legitimate age.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 2:1
verses.text: The Decrees of the Same, from the Codex of Decrees in Sixteen Books, from the Fifth Book, and the Seventh and Ninth Chapters.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 2:3
verses.text: That the oblation of the altar should be made each Lord's day.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 2:4
verses.text: We decree that on each Lord's day the oblation of the altar should be made by men and women in bread and wine, in order that by means of these sacrifices they may be released from the burden of their sins.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 2:6
verses.text: That an illiterate presbyter may not venture to celebrate mass.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 2:7
verses.text: The sacrifice is not to be accepted from the hand of a priest who is not competent to discharge the prayers or actions (actiones) and other observances in the mass according to religious usage.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:3
verses.text: )  The early Bishops of Rome, who till the time of Sylvester (a.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:5
verses.text: ) were, with few exceptions, like him pure and faithful shepherds, and not lords over God's heritage, shall here be enumerated.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:6
verses.text: But first let us settle in few words the historic facts as to the See.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:8
verses.text: Paul was, clearly, the Apostolic founder of the Roman church, as appears from Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:10
verses.text: Peter seems to have come to Rome not long before his martyrdom.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:11
verses.text: Linus and Cletus could not have been Bishops of Rome, for they were merely coadjutors of the Apostles during their lifetime.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:12
verses.text: Clement was the first who succeeded to their work after their death; and thus he should unquestionably be made the first of the Roman bishops,—a position of which he was eminently worthy, for his was the spirit of St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:13
verses.text: Peter himself, as set forth in that incomparable passage of his first Epistle, in which the Apostle bids all his brethren to be shepherds indeed, and "ensamples to the flock".

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:14
verses.text: We may therefore give the outline of this history as follows:—.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:16
verses.text: Paul was the "Apostle of the Gentiles," and St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:19
verses.text: Paul came first to Rome, and organized the Christians he found there after the pattern "ordained in all the churches".

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:20
verses.text: He had Linus for his coadjutor, being himself a prisoner, until he went into Spain.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:24
verses.text: ), and laboured with the Jewish Christians there, St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:25
verses.text: Paul recognising his mission among them.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:26
verses.text: This Apostle (soon thrown into prison) had Cletus for his coadjutor.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:27
verses.text: In the Neronian persecution Linus seem to have suffered with St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:28
verses.text: Paul, and probably Cletus as well.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:32
verses.text: Peter, therefore, about to suffer himself, ordains Clement to succeed him.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:33
verses.text: As he was the first "successor of the Apostles," therefore, in the See of Rome, and the first who had jurisdiction there (for the Apostles certainly never surrendered their mission to their coadjutors), it follows that Clement was the first Bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:34
verses.text: This is confirmed by the earliest testimony,—that of Ignatius.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:35
verses.text: It agrees with Tertullian's testimony, and he speaks (as a lawyer and expert) from "the registers".

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:36
verses.text: Irenaeus, speaking less precisely, may be harmonized with these testimonies without violence to what he reports.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:134
verses.text: the Bishops of Rome are canonical primates; the Bishops of New Rome primates equally, but second on the list; then Alexandria, Antioch, Ephesus.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:135
verses.text: The Councils of Constantinople and Chalcedon state that these primacies were awarded because Rome and New Rome were the capitals of the oecumene, or empire.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:136
verses.text: The primacy conferred no authority over the sister Sees of Apostolic foundation, and recognised no inequality among bishops, save those of such honorary distinction.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:140
verses.text: ) Sylvester to Gregory the Great, and his successor, who lived but one year, the Bishops of Rome were canonical primates.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:142
verses.text: accepted the court title of "Universal Bishop" (a.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:144
verses.text: ) from the Emperor Phocas, but it was not recognised by the Church.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:145
verses.text: From this time to Adrian I.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:146
verses.text: many Bishops of Rome vied with those of Constantinople to augment their honour and power.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:147
verses.text: The establishment of the Western Empire (a.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:149
verses.text: ) made their ambitious claims acceptable to the Latins; and they became primates of all Christendom in Western estimation, with extra-canonical and indefinite claims as "successors of St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:154
verses.text: ), by means of the False Decretals, gave shape to these extra-canonical claims, abrogated the Nicene Constitutions in the West by making these Decretals canon-law, and asserted a supremacy over the old patriarchares, which they never allowed:  hence the schism of the West from the Apostolic Sees of the East, and from the primitive discipline which established the Papacy, as now understood.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:158
verses.text: ) the Latin churches recognised this Papacy more or less; the Gallicans resisting, though feebly, by asserting their "liberties," according to Nicene Constitutions.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:160
verses.text: , honestly persuaded that the Decretals were authentic, enforced these spurious canons without reference to antiquity, and pronounced the title of "Pope" the sole and peculiar dignity of the Bishops of Rome a.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:165
verses.text: The churches of England and France, which claimed to be outside of the "holy Roman Empire," under kings whose own crowns were "imperial," maintained a perpetual contest with the Papacy, admitted the extra-canonical "primacy," but resisted all claims to "supremacy".

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:166
verses.text: School-doctrines were framed and enforced, but were extra-symbolic, and of no Catholic authority.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:167
verses.text: They abused the episcopate to exalt the Papacy.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:168
verses.text: The Council of Trent, after the Northern revolt from the Papacy and School-doctrine, sat seventeen years (from a.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:172
verses.text: ) framing the "Roman-Catholic Church" out of the remainder of national churches, depriving them of their nationalities, and making out of them all, with the missions in America, one mixed confederation, to which it gave a new creed and new organic laws; debasing the entire episcopate (which it denied to be an order distinct from that of presbyters), and making the Pope the "Universal Bishop," with other bishops reduced to presbyters, acting as his local vicars.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:173
verses.text: The Gallicans feebly withstood these changes, and strove to maintain the primitive Constitutions by accommodations with their theory of the "Gallican liberties," as founded by St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:175
verses.text: Gallicanism was extinguished by Pope Pius IX.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:176
verses.text: , who proclaimed the Pope "infallible," and thus raised his "supremacy" into an article of the Roman-Catholic faith.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:177
verses.text: The following is the modern creed of "Roman Catholics," which, with the latest additions, embodies a library of dogmas in the eleventh article, and now, since the decree of Infallibility makes the entire Bullary (a vast library of decrees and definitions), equally part of the Creed.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:178
verses.text: The Trentine Creed, or the Creed of Pius IV.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:181
verses.text: I most stedfastly admit and embrace Apostolical and ecclesiastical traditions, and all other observances and constitutions of the Church.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:182
verses.text: I also admit the Holy Scripture according to that sense which our holy mother the Church has held, and does hold, to which it belongs to judge of the true sense and interpretations of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:183
verses.text: Neither will I ever take and interpret them otherwise than according to the unanimous consent of the Fathers.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:184
verses.text: I also profess that there are truly and properly seven sacraments of the New Law, instituted by Jesus Christ our Lord, and necessary for the salvation of mankind, though not all for every one; to wit, Baptism, Confirmation, Eucharist, Penance, Extreme Unction, Order, and Matrimony; and that they confer grace; and that of these, Baptism, Confirmation, and Order cannot be reiterated without sacrilege.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:185
verses.text: I also receive and admit the received and approved ceremonies of the Catholic Church in the solemn administration of the aforesaid sacraments.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:186
verses.text: I embrace and receive all and every one of the things which have been defined and declared in the holy Council of Trent concerning original sin and justification.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:187
verses.text: I profess, likewise, that in the Mass there is offered to God a true, proper, and propitiatory sacrifice for the living and the dead; and that in the most holy sacrament of the Eucharist there is truly, really, and substantially, the body and blood, together with the soul and divinity, of our Lord Jesus Christ; and that there is made a conversion of the whole substance of the bread into the body, and of the whole substance of the wine into the blood, which conversion the Catholic Church calls Transubstantiation.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:188
verses.text: I also confess that under either kind alone Christ is received whole and entire, and a true sacrament.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:189
verses.text: I constantly hold that there is a Purgatory, and that the souls therein detained are helped by the suffrages of the faithful.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:190
verses.text: Likewise, that the saints, reigning together with Christ, are to be honoured and invocated, and that they offer prayers to God for us, and that their relics are to be respected.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:191
verses.text: I most firmly assert that the images of Christ, of the mother of God, ever virgin, and also of the saints, ought to be had and retained, and that due honour and veneration is to be given them.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:192
verses.text: I also affirm that the power of indulgences was left by Christ in the Church, and that the use of them is most wholesome to Christian people.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:193
verses.text: I acknowledge the Holy Catholic Apostolic Roman Church for the mother and mistress of all churches; and I promise true obedience to the Bishop of Rome, successor to St.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:194
verses.text: Peter, Prince of the Apostles, and Vicar of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:195
verses.text: I likewise undoubtedly receive and profess all other things delivered, defined, and declared by the sacred Canons, and general Councils, and particularly by the holy Council of Trent.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:196
verses.text: And I condemn, reject, and anathematize all things contrary thereto, and all heresies whatsoever, condemned, rejected, and anathematized by the Church.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:197
verses.text: This true Catholic faith, without which no one can be saved, I N.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:199
verses.text: do at this present freely confess and sincerely hold; and I promise most constantly to retain, and confess the same entire and unviolated, with God's assistance, to the end of my life,  Amen.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:203
verses.text: , , the new article of the Immaculate Conception of the Virgin Mary, to be believed as necessary to salvation.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:206
verses.text: — To which was added (December, ) the whole Syllabus.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:209
verses.text: — To which was added (July , ) the new dogma of Infallibility.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:210
verses.text: Observe, this "Creed" is imposed on all in the Roman Obedience, and especially on those who enter it from other communions, as that without which no one can be saved.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:211
verses.text: The Catholic Creed of Nicaea is not sufficient.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 3:212
verses.text: But the Seventh Canon of Ephesus not only forbids the composition of any other creed, but especially adds:  "Those who shall presume to compose another creed, or to produce or offer it to persons desiring to return to the acknowledgment of the truth…from any heresy whatever, shall be deposed…if bishops or other clergy, and if they be laymen they shall be anathematized".

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:3
verses.text: )  On this stupendous fraud I quote from Dupin, as follows:—  "Among the number of Constantine's edicts I do not place the Donation which goes under his name.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:4
verses.text: Some have attributed this false monument to the author of the collection (Decretals) ascribed to Isidore, he being a notorious forger of such kind of writings; and this conjecture is more probable than some others.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:5
verses.text: "By this Donation, Constantine is supposed to give to the Bishops of Rome the sovereignty of the city, and of the provinces of the Western Empire.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:6
verses.text: I note some of the reasons which clearly prove this instrument to be a forgery:—  "  Not one of the ancients mentions this pretended liberality of the emperor.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:7
verses.text: How could Eusebius, and all the other historians who wrote about Constantine, have passed over in silence, had it been a reality, the gift of a Western Empire to the Bishop of Rome?  "  Not one of the Bishops of Rome ever refers to such a donation, though it would have been much to their advantage so to do.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:8
verses.text: "  It is dated falsely, and under consuls who flourished when Constantine was unbaptized; yet his baptism is referred to in this instrument.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:9
verses.text: Again, the city of Constantinople is mentioned in it, although it was called Byzantium for ten years subsequent to its date.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:10
verses.text: "  Not only is the style very different from the genuine edicts of the emperor, but it is full of terms and phrases that came into use much after the time of Constantine.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:11
verses.text: "  How comes it that he should have given one-half of his empire to the Bishop of Rome, including the city of Rome itself, without any one ever hearing of it for hundreds of years after?  "  The falsities and absurdities of this edict demonstrate that it was composed by an ignorant impostor.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:12
verses.text: Thus by it, for example, the Pope is permitted to wear a crown of gold, and a fabulous history is given of the emperor's baptism by Sylvester:  also, it contains a history of the emperor's miraculous cure of leprosy by Sylvester, all which do plainly prove the forgery.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:13
verses.text: It is certain that the city of Rome was governed by the emperor, and that the Bishops of Rome were subject to him, and obeyed him, as all his other subjects.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:14
verses.text: "All that we have said plainly shows that the edict of Donation that bears the name of Constantine is wholly supposititious; but it is not so easy to find out who was the author.

verses.name: Decretal: Decrees of Fabian 4:15
verses.text: However it be, this document has neither any use nor authority".
